div.a: April 24, 2020 Update from Superintendent Flores: welcome new principals, community service hours update, new food distribution for weekends, GUSD photo collages and GHS Choir sings Imagine

div.p: April 24, 2020
Dear GUSD staff and families:
This week has been incredibly busy and there is lots of news to share with you today. Here are the updates about what’s happening in the district:

Extended food service: Beginning today, in addition to the meals that we are serving Monday-Friday from 10:00-1:00, our food services department is offering weekend meals to families who pick up food at our seven school sites on Fridays. Friday meal bags will now contain breakfast and lunch for Saturday and Sunday. Parents will receive one bag with all items (entrees, beverages, and fruit or veggie). Please note: weekend lunches will be served cold and families will need to heat them up at home. In April, we have served over 45,000 meals to Gilroy children.

New Administrators: At the April 23, 2020 Board meeting, we welcomed two new principals to our administrative team: Camille Epps will be the new principal at El Roble Elementary and Greg Kapaku will be the new principal at Gilroy High School next school year. Camille has served in our district for the last four years and Greg returns to the Gilroy Unified School District after two years as assistant principal at Westmont High School. You can read the full announcement here.

School Recognitions: I want to acknowledge four of our school communities for recognitions they received this week. GECA, Christopher High School and Gilroy High School were all named top schools in California by US News and World Report. GECA was named the sixth-ranked high school in California and 76th in the nation. Additionally this week, Rucker Elementary School was honored as an Asset Champion by the YMCA of Silicon Valley for their Caring School Community. These recognitions are a testament to the dedication and commitment to educational excellence by the staff, students and families at these school sites, and in our district overall. I am so proud of the work our staff put in every day to develop young minds and world citizens at each of our school sites.

High School Graduations: Our discussions about high school graduation continue to occur. Your thoughts and feelings have been shared with me, our leadership team, and the school board in a variety of ways: letters, petitions, and public comment at board meetings. Thank you for continuing to share with us. Like you, we are looking for different ways to celebrate our graduating seniors and we wish that there were easy answers for all of you.

Our High School Principals and Director of Secondary Education Dr. Deborah Padilla have been meeting for several weeks to discuss different options for graduations. They have investigated virtual options, discussed delaying the graduations, brainstormed about other creative ways to do graduations and checked to see what other districts are doing.

We understand that this year's seniors have been greatly impacted by the COVID19 pandemic. We wish to share our deep-felt sympathy for the loss of so many events that only happen once during a graduate’s senior year. Unfortunately, until the shelter-in-place executive order is substantially modified or lifted, we cannot hold our traditional graduations with thousands of people in attendance.

In other news for seniors, last night the Board of Education modified the Community Service Hours requirement for the Class of 2020 and 2021. For this year’s graduating class, the Board has waived the requirement completely.

Secondary Grading Policy: The Board of Education also officially modified the grading policy for all secondary students at last night’s Board Meeting. Information on grading for secondary students (middle and high school) can be found here.

The Duration of Distance Learning: I am often asked how long will distance learning be in place and when can students and staff return to our buildings. The short answer is that no one knows that answer. Dr. Sara Cody, Public Health Director, and California Governor Newsom often share that the data on COVID19 will drive the decision-making process and that the health and safety of the public is their top priority. At this point, it is premature to speculate a definitive date for a return to campuses.

We do know that distance learning is going to be in place for a while. I have been attending bi-weekly meetings with Public Health Department officials and Santa Clara County Superintendents since early March. The message that has been directly conveyed to superintendents is that the shelter in place restrictions for public schools will not be lifted during the summer and thus, summer school will be provided through distance learning. We have also been told that distance learning may be in place in the fall. In my view, the likelihood that classes will resume as they were before the pandemic in the fall is at least a 50:50 proposition. We have also heard in these meetings and it has been stated in the news that large group events will not be allowed in this calendar year. I am as eager as you are to return to school and a sense of normalcy for our students, families and staff members and I am looking forward to that time with great anticipation.

Chromebook Distribution changes: In the meantime, we continue to work hard to provide support systems for our students and families through distance learning. This week, we completed our bulk distribution dates for Chromebooks. We have additional Chromebooks available for families to use, but the method of requesting a device has changed. Moving forward, should you have a need for a Chromebook, please work with your child’s teacher to have them communicate with our Ed Services team. Teachers can request Chromebooks for students, or you may send an email to questions@gilroyunified.org, and include the student’s name, student ID number, telephone number and mailing address. At this time, we are not able to accommodate requests for Chromebooks over the phone or using social media platforms. To date, we have distributed more than 3,200 Chromebooks to our GUSD families. If you have a need for technology, please don’t hesitate to reach out.

New WiFi Opportunities for families: In an attempt to provide WiFi access to a greater number of families, the District has entered into an agreement to provide WiFi hotspots using busses parked at Gilroy High School and Christopher High School, as well as in the rural neighborhoods of the Rucker attendance areas. Details, such as dates and times, are still forthcoming, but I know that WiFi access will give more students a greater chance to access distance learning opportunities and connect with their teachers and classmates on a virtual platform.

Retrieval of items left on campus: We’ve had received questions about the possibility of retrieving items left on campus following the shelter in place orders on March 13. Our buildings are still closed to any person other than essential staff. Once the orders are lifted, we will notify you of the protocol to retrieve those items.

Closing Comments: So many things have brought me joy this week. The Brownell Middle School modernization project continues to move forward at an expedited pace. This week, we kicked off the South Valley Middle School redesign project. The timeline for this rebuild will be 3-4 years, and SVMS will be a state of the art middle school campus upon its completion. We announced two GUSD “Behind the Scenes All-Stars:” Gilroy High School Office Manager, Mary Ann Mukai, and GUSD Information Technology Director, Maribel Guizar. You can read more about their contributions to our school communities here. We compiled 30 collages of staff members from 15 school sites, support staff and our after school partners and posted them all on our Facebook page. Seeing the participation from over 300 staff members sharing their virtual love with our students and families makes me smile. You can see all the collages here. Please share these photos with your children. Our staff members miss them as much as they miss our staff.

Finally, I invite you to spend five minutes watching the Gilroy High School choir, directed by Jonathan Souza, performing Imagine, by John Lennon: Their performance demonstrates the resiliency of our students and families, and exemplifies the unifying power of music.
Take care of each other,
Dr. Deborah A. Flores, Ph.D.
Superintendent, Gilroy Unified School District

li.a: Will Students Return to School for 2019-20 School Year?
What are the symptoms of COVID-19?

h2.a: Will Students Return to School for 2019-20 School Year?

div.p: On April 1, 2020, the Santa Clara County Office of Education announced that all schools in the county will transition to distance learning models as described by the California Department of Education.

Students in GUSD will not return to the classroom for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. The 2019-20 school year has not ended. Distance learning for GUSD students begins Monday, April 13, 2020.

Flexible learning opportunities (i.e. online learning, Google classroom, and hard copy packets), for students to utilize during school closures are currently posted on the GUSD website. Hard copy packets are available to be picked up at the seven school sites distributing food, weekdays, from 10 am-1 pm.

h2.a: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?

For some people, the symptoms are like having a cold; for others, the symptoms are quite severe or even life-threatening. In either case, it is important to check with your child’s health-care provider (or yours) and follow instructions about staying home or away from public spaces to prevent the spread of the virus.
